awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: GP-IMPACT: A Geopathway Utilizing High-Tech Geoscience Experiences for Recruitment and Retention -- A Collaboration between PBSC and FAU
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1
This project aims to ameliorate the current and increasing severe shortage of geoscientists in the U.S. workforce. The goal is to institutionalize a transformative model to effect a long-term, sustained increase in recruitment and retention of students from Palm Beach State College (PBSC), a two-year college (2YC), particularly more women and underrepresented minorities (URMs), into geoscience programs at Florida Atlantic University (FAU), a four-year (4yr) institution in South Florida. The proposed activities of this model, such as embedding workforce readiness components into the science curriculum at FAU and PBSC, developing and implementing Exploring Geopaths Summer Institute (EGSI) and Undergraduate Geopaths Research Experiences (UGRE), which will both expose and train more students in cutting-edge geoscience technologies, support and align with NSF's Harnessing the Data Revolution, and Future of Work Big Ideas. PIs anticipate a sustained increase in graduation rates of skilled geoscientists who will enter the workforce ready and pursue employment opportunities in much needed sectors such as: energy, oil and gas, environmental services, mining, research institutes, and federal, state or local governments. Through this project PIs also intend to position PBSC and FAU students and faculty in line with NSF's INCLUDES Big Idea that "aspires to transform education and career pathways to help broaden participation in science and engineering".

Part 2
This project aims to ameliorate the current and increasing severe shortage of geoscientists in the U.S. workforce. Our goal is to institutionalize a transformative model to effect a long-term, sustained increase in recruitment and retention of students from Palm Beach State College (PBSC), a two-year college (2YC), particularly more women and underrepresented minorities (URMs), into geoscience programs at Florida Atlantic University (FAU), a four-year (4yr) institution in South Florida. By targeting the diverse student population at PBSC, the project will significantly increase the enrollment, and the number of females and URMs in geoscience programs at FAU. As part of the transformative model PIs will implement: (1) Growing the transfer student pipeline and increasing student diversity by recruiting geoscience majors from PBSC, revising and strengthening the transfer articulation agreement (Link Program), implementing geoscience-specific 2+2 transfer flight plans, developing a cross-institutional collaborative advising protocol framework, and initiating and embedding career readiness components directly into the geosciences courses taken by PBSC students prior to transferring to FAU. (2) Developing a new Exploring Geopaths Summer Institute (EGSI), with authentic experiences utilizing a rich spectrum of geoscience high-tech and field methods, designed to attract, and recruit PBSC students. (3) Developing a new Undergraduate Geopaths Research Experiences (UGRE), designed to motivate and retain transfer students early in their matriculation into geoscience degree programs at FAU. (4) Enhancing the departmental culture with faculty and peer mentors to make it a more welcoming, and supportive environment for students. PIs anticipate the outcomes will position this model as one that can be easily adopted by other institutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Integrative and Collaborative Education and Research (ICER)

por.por_cntn:
As a result of this program, the collaborative GP-IMPACT teams at Palm Beach State College (2-year) and Florida Atlantic University (4-year) worked together to grow PBSC student awareness of FAU geoscience degree programs and regional careers in geoscience and climate change. The outcomes from this project include:

1. Articulation Agreement. This articulation agreement facilitates a transfer pathway for Palm Beach State College Associate of Arts (AA, 2-year) students to undergraduate degree programs leading to a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) or a Bachelor of Science (B.S.) with a focus in either Geography or Geology at Florida Atlantic University (FAU). Information about this opportunity can be found at the PBSC website at https://www.palmbeachstate.edu/transfer/as-degree-transfer-agreements.aspx

2. Summer Camps and Research Experiences.  The GP-IMPACT teams developed and implemented annual  camps called, Exploring Geopaths Summer Institute (EGSI), and Undergraduate Geopaths Research Experiences (UGRE), which will both expose and train more PBSC students in cutting-edge geoscience technologies and support.  Camps consisted of both 8-day and 1-day camps.  Students were provided stipends, housing, and meals.  This deliverable also saw student participants meet FAU geoscience graduate students and department faculty with academic course plans, and representatives from industry partners on career opportunities regionally, nationally, and globally in a variety of industries,research, and academia.

3. Canvas Course Shell. The GP-IMPACT staff member who served as academic advisor and faculty member teaching geology and earth science courses, developed a Canvas course shell that is shared with other PBSC physical science faculty to share with students in their courses. In addition she created a similar Canvas course shell for FAU faculty. This course shell describe the transfer pathway, highlights students in the program.

4. Geoscience Promotional Videos. We have completed a two-minute geoscience program promotional video, to market Geosciences Department programs at FAU and geoscience in general. It has been put on YouTube (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IvUpwsh26xU), the FAU Geoscience department website (geosciences.fau.edu), FAU College of Science social media. A shorter version of the video (45 seconds) was edited from the long version for recruiting campaigns through Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/72083467621/posts/10159191411842622) and  Instagram.  They are also used to recruit students for the summer programs.

5. FAU Geoscience Career Booklet. We completed a geoscience career booklet used for student career planning. It is a 10-page document that details the relevant and rewarding career opportunities based on US Department of Labor statistics. Importantly, the booklet highlights the successful careers of FAU geoscience recent alumni. The booklet is useful for students to guide their career planning. 

6. Department Webpage Update and Alumni Highlights. With the support from the FAU College of Science communications team, the webpages have been updated with the new videos, alumni highlights, field camp photos, and transfer information. We collected testimonials from a dozen recent alumni and used these to better inform potential students about the exciting opportunities in geoscience (http://www.geosciences.fau.edu/news/student-highlights/index.php).

7. Demographic Shifts in Department and Program Enrollment.  The research conducted in this project reveal that the overall minority percentage of FAU Geoscience undergraduate students significantly increased (33% to 41%) during this project duration, so are the percentage of two selected groups: Hispanic or Latino (17% to 21%), and Black or African American (8% to 13%). However, the geosciences numbers are still much lower than the College of Science average, even though the college numbers  remained almost unchanged.


Last Modified: 04/22/2024
Modified by: Becky Mercer
